Line 37: Line 37:
On 31 January 2011, the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' ran an exclusive interview with Bashar al-Assad, [[President]] of [[Syria]], in which he said that it was time to reform. In a comment on the protests in [[Protests in Egypt|Egypt]], [[2010â2011 Tunisian uprising|Tunisia]] and [[2011 Yemeni protests|Yemen]], he said that a "new era" is coming to the [[Middle East]], and that Arab rulers would need to do more to accommodate their people's rising political and economic aspirations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703833204576114712441122894.html |title=Interview With Syrian President Bashar al-Assad |publisher=wsj.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704832704576114340735033236.html |title=Syria Strongman: Time for 'Reform' |publisher=wsj.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-31}}</ref> However, President Bashar al-Assad also declared that his state is immune from the kinds of mass protests that have taken place in Egypt.<ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2011/02/02/middle-east-protests-syria-egypt/ FOX News opinion].</ref>
On 31 January 2011, the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' ran an exclusive interview with Bashar al-Assad, [[President]] of [[Syria]], in which he said that it was time to reform. In a comment on the protests in [[Protests in Egypt|Egypt]], [[2010â2011 Tunisian uprising|Tunisia]] and [[2011 Yemeni protests|Yemen]], he said that a "new era" is coming to the [[Middle East]], and that Arab rulers would need to do more to accommodate their people's rising political and economic aspirations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748703833204576114712441122894.html |title=Interview With Syrian President Bashar al-Assad |publisher=wsj.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704832704576114340735033236.html |title=Syria Strongman: Time for 'Reform' |publisher=wsj.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-31}}</ref> However, President Bashar al-Assad also declared that his state is immune from the kinds of mass protests that have taken place in Egypt.<ref>[http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2011/02/02/middle-east-protests-syria-egypt/ FOX News opinion].</ref>
